title: It Seemed Too Good to be True... And It Was

transcript: - Ariana Grande is performing a cosmically mind-bending concert in Fortnite? No, thanks. I'll take some tech news. - [Man] Good choice. - Apple has caused a stir among tech and privacy enthusiasts by announcing plans to scan the company's devices for content that depicts the abuse of children. Apple published a press release and a technical breakdown of how this would work, which involves using on-device machine learning to detect images that match a known database of image hashes. If a certain threshold of matches is reached, Apple will provide information to the authorities. Now, obviously this is a noble goal, two thumbs up, but the implementation has privacy advocates worried that a similar system could easily be used to scan for any number of things. The Electronic Frontier Foundation calls it a backdoor into your private life, while others are pointing out that such a move is a bit strange coming from Apple, who is never going to live down that CES billboard about things staying on your iPhone. The system won't be implemented until later this year, so there's a bit more time to argue about hypothetical situations and reference George Orwell. - [Man] This is just like - A lot. - [Man] "1984". - But there's even more Apple news thanks to a number of documents relating to their legal fight with Epic Games being released this week. One of the more juicy ones actually concerns Google, who apparently called Epic's plans to sidestep the Play Store a contagion because it threatened Google's dominant app platform. The court filings also revealed that Google called the Android sideloading process abysmal and contemplated buying a majority stake in Epic to stop their lawsuit, because when you're rich, they let you do it. (Linus makes playful noise) Another document lays out Apple's anti-Epic arguments in detail, essentially saying that they're only after money, since Epic has admitted at times that current antitrust law may not be on their side. In the midst of all of this though, developer's complaints to Apple this week about scam apps that were promoted in the Australian iOS App Store. One app was charging $13 a week to remove ads, which goes against Apple's promise of rejecting expensive apps that try to cheat users with irrationally high prices.
